Description: Large scarab carved from steatite; rather well-defined back with quite detailed clypeus, and prothorax and elytra marked by roughly incised double lines; V-incisions on elytra at junction with prothorax on each side; side view unknown; underside incised with motif arranged horizontally consisting of god Bes flanked by monkeys which raise their hands in a worshipping attitude; pierced lengthwise; glaze worn; in yellow-brown steatite; modern glue on back of scarab.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Scarab Factory (according to museum register)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The depiction of Bes worshipped by two monkeys is well attested on scarabs and scaraboids, Naukratis included (see Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 86.676 published in Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVIII, no. 149). Bes holds here a solar aspect, since worshipping monkeys are very often associated with solar symbols such as scarab, obelisk and the cartouche of Menkheperra (Jaeger 1982, 213 § 1393). B. Jaeger lists other occurrences of this design on convex rectangular plaques and scaraboids, most of which can be dated to the Ramesside Period (Jaeger 1982, 218-219 § 1408) and he thinks that the stone scarabs which depicts Bes found in Naukratis should probably be dated to this period too (Jaeger 1982, 205 § 1366, n. 868). However, a scarab in green glazed steatite showing a similar design was discovered in the Third Intermediate Period cemetery at Matmar (Brunton, G. 1948. Matmar, London, pl. LXIII, 108, mainly dated to the 8th-7th c. BC) and another example quoted by Jaeger himself originates from the Kushite cemetery of Sanam (Griffith 1923, pl. XLV, 8). Though Naukratis scarabs could be archaizing copies of Ramesside types, it is more likely that they are genuine Ramesside ones (on the various early scarabs from Naukratis see: Masson forthcoming). For further parallels see: Hornung and Staehelin 1976, no. 695-696 (scaraboid and scarab in steatite). Brunton, G. 1948. Matmar, London. Griffith, F.L. 1923. ‘Oxford excavation in Nubia’, Annals of Archaeology and Anthropology, Liverpool 10. Essai de classification et datation des scarabées Menkhéperrê. Fribourg. Masson, A. forthcoming, ‘Egyptian Naukratis: the early evidence’, in A. Wodzińska (ed.), Delta and Sinai Current research, Proceedings of the conference in the University of Warsaw, Warsaw, April 25-27 2013.
